plants.name: Aster amellus
plants.description: Aster amellus is a perennial wildflower native to Europe, known for its daisy-like flowers with vibrant purple petals and yellow centers. It thrives in temperate climates and blooms in late summer to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
plants.funFact: Michaelmas daisies are often associated with the feast of St. Michael (Michaelmas) on September 29, marking the transition to autumn.

plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: Rudbeckia hirta is a North American native wildflower famous for its bright yellow petals and dark brown central cones. It thrives in a variety of habitats including prairies and roadsides, blooming from mid-summer into early fall and providing valuable nectar to insects.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans can reseed themselves abundantly, making them a staple in wildflower mixes and native plant gardens.

plants.name: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis
plants.description: A tropical shrub widely cultivated in warm climates, known for its large, showy flowers with overlapping petals that come in various colors including red, pink, orange, and white. It blooms year-round in frost-free areas, including September, and attracts hummingbirds and butterflies.
plants.funFact: Hibiscus flowers open in the morning and usually wilt by the evening, lasting only a day but opening anew daily during blooming seasons.

plants.name: Solidago canadensis
plants.description: A late summer to autumn blooming perennial native to North America, characterized by clusters of small, bright yellow flowers that form plume-like heads. Goldenrod often grows in meadows and along roadsides, and it plays a vital role in supporting pollinators late in the growing season.
plants.funFact: Despite common misconceptions, goldenrod is not a major cause of hay fever; ragweed pollen, which blooms at the same time, is usually responsible.
